entities: Regional Initiative for Peace in Burundi
summary:
The Security Council,
Recalling its resolutions on Burundi, particularly 1545, 1565, 1577, and 1596, and statements by its President, 
Reaffirming commitment to Burundi's sovereignty, independence, territorial integrity, and unity, 
Reaffirming support for the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement, 
Welcoming positive achievements, including the approval of the post-transitional Constitution and a declaration signed on 15 May 2005 by the President and the leader of Palipehutu-FNL, 
Urging the international community to increase assistance for Burundi's development, 
Welcoming the imminent holding of elections, 
Encouraging women's participation in the political process, 
Noting progress in security sector reform and disarmament, 
Paying tribute to the Regional Initiative for Burundi and the Facilitation of South Africa, 
Condemning violence, human rights violations, and the Gatumba massacre, 
Reiterating the need to bring an end to impunity in Burundi, 
Decides to extend ONUB's mandate until 1 December 2005; 
Calls upon Burundian parties to ensure the Transition's success; 
Looks forward to the Secretary-General's recommendations by 15 November 2005 on the UN's role in supporting Burundi.

6. Welcomes ONUB's efforts to implement the zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse, requests the Secretary-General to continue taking necessary actions, and urges troop-contributing countries to investigate and punish related acts involving their personnel;

7. Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
